with the Co atoms being partially positively charged and Sn atoms hav-
ing an average valence below 2. For direct determination of the surface
ultrahigh vacuum conditions to expose the (001) surface. Scanning
tunneling microscope (STM) images were collected in situ at 2 K and
are shown in Fig. 4C. The cleaved surface exhibits a typical Kagome-
lattice atomic structure, indicating a Co layer at the surface. Such a
cleave is energetically favorable because it exposes the smallest surface
Sn bond can be easily broken because of the large
The high-quality bulk single crystal with well-defined surface termina-
tion provides an ideal platform for understanding the surface catalytic
process. Although the details of the mechanismof the O
mation remain unresolved, there is a consensus that the initial discharge
of hydroxide ions at a catalytically active center is the initial step. For
transition metals such as Co, Ni, and Fe, the crystal field formed by dif-
ferent types of coordination results in distinct spin states and
with the oxygen-related adsorbates, making electron transfer between
the active sites and adsorbates more favorable. This results the
of surface active centers as an activity descriptor for OER and oxygen
atoms in the bulk are octahedrally coordinated and the
Fig. 4. Surface structure and OER mechanism.

representation of the favored OH uptake with the Co 3
orbitals. The exfoliation between the S-Sn plane break the octahedral symmetry of the surface Co atoms in the
Kagome lattice (highlighted by yellow triangle). The empty 3
orbital of the OH group, resulting in a strong bonding between them. (

single crystal with one OH group bonded to the Co atoms. Electronic charges are distributed in the vicinity of Sn atoms. However,
